title: ag.algebraic geometry - A morphism $F$ of algebraic stacks is quasi-compact iff $|F|$ is quasi-compact
body: This is 5.6.3. of Laumon, Moret-Bailly's "Champs Algeriques". Let $S$ be a scheme, $\mathscr{X, Y}$ algebraic stacks over $S$ , and $F : \mathscr{X \to Y}$ a morphism. Then $F$ is quasi-compact (i.e., for every quasi-compact scheme $Y$ and every $Y \to \mathscr{Y}$ , the stack $\mathscr{X} \times_\mathscr{Y} Y$ is quasi-compact) iff $|F|$ is quasi-compact. ( $|F|$ is the canonical continuous map of topological spaces $|\mathscr{X}| \to |\mathscr{Y}|$ .) In this text, the authors assume that $S$ is quasi-separated and that all algebraic stacks are quasi-separated over the base scheme. But I want to show this highlighted statement for non-qs base schemes and for non-qs algebraic stacks. In the proof of "if" part, the authors says that, for quasi-compact algebraic stack $\mathscr{X, Y}$ and a morphism $F : \mathscr{X \to Y}$ , $F$ is quasi-compact. I think that this needs the quasi-separation of $S$ and $\mathscr{Y}$ . Taking a look at the Stacks Project, I couldn't find its references. Is this holds for non qs stacks? If so, how can I show it? ag.algebraic-geometry algebraic-stacks Share Cite Improve this question Follow edited Aug 4, 2020 at 14:01 asked Aug 4, 2020 at 13:05 k.j. 1,364 9 9 silver badges 21 21 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 2 $\begingroup$ Can you remind us what $|F|$ is? Is it a map on coarse moduli spaces? $\endgroup$ David Roberts –  David Roberts ♦ 2020-08-04 13:45:54 +00:00 Commented Aug 4, 2020 at 13:45 $\begingroup$ @DavidRoberts Thanks for pointing out. I edited it. $\endgroup$ k.j. –  k.j. 2020-08-04 14:02:37 +00:00 Commented Aug 4, 2020 at 14:02 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
